Award.AwardTitle: NSF/DOE Solar Hydrogen Fuel: Tunable Semiconductor/Catalyst Interfaces for Efficient Solar WaterSplitting

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Much research has gone into creating new materials and processes for making solar fuels cell devices that convert and store the energy in sunlight as fuels (hydrogen and hydrocarbons) from renewable feedstocks (water and carbon dioxide). However, no commercial products of this type yet exist due to the high cost of fuel cell materials, low solar to chemical conversion efficiencies, instability and short lifetime. An award is being made to Profs. Charles Dismukes, Eric Garfunkel and Martha Greenblatt of Rutgers University through the joint NSF/DOE Solar H2 Fuel Solicitation to create new nanomaterials and combine them in a special fashion to produce a new device that circumvents these limitations, while increasing the solar efficiency by a factor of 2. The new materials in the solar photovoltaic cells will be integrated with existing catalysts to make standalone light-driven electrolyzers for splitting water into its elements and, separately, reducing carbon dioxide to a liquid fuel. The device will feature earth abundant catalysts that rival the efficiency of existing platinum group catalysts, yet are economical and scalable. Syntheses of new composite photovoltaic materials to be used as solar absorbers for the anode and cathode that feature complementary spectral coverage are predicted to deliver a two-fold increase in solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency relative to current systems. New methods for integration of catalysts with solar absorbers will be devised. Attainment of these goals read directly on environmental and energy security benefits to the USA.

The goals of this award require the design of new materials and the coupling of them into new working devices. The specific milestones to be achieved are: 1) To achieve a two-fold increase to 10% of the current state-of-the-art solar-to-hydrogen efficiency by constructing a tandem photoelectrochemical cell with catalysts for Oxygen evolution (cubic LiCoO2/ionomer) and Hydrogen evolution (Ni5P4/ionomer) coupled to (dual) bandgap absorbers as photoanode (perovskite oxynitrides ABO3-xNx) and photocathode (pn-silicon), using an alkaline exchange membrane as a hydroxide conducting medium. 2) Synthesize selected members of the perovskite oxynitride series ABO3-xNx where A = alkaline earth or rare earth cation and B = Ti, V, Zr, Nb, Ta, and with B site substitutions Nb or Ta for Ti. 3) Prepare thin films of the foregoing perovskites, first by pulsed laser deposition (PLD), and, in subsequent years, explore other methods to grow gradient films. 4) Characterize the optical bandgaps and photoinduced carrier lifetimes of these materials prior to attaching O2 evolution catalysts. 5) Using PLD, prepare thin films of cubic LiCoO2 both in direct contact with the photoanode and as a buried junction with intervening transparent conductors. 6) Produce stable interfaces between Ni5P4 with various photocathodes (silicon and other low bandgap semiconductors) to achieve efficient electron capture for H2 evolution. 7) Produce stable interfaces between Ni5P4 and alkaline exchange ionomers to achieve efficient hydroxide transport, slower charge recombination, and long term stability. 8) Investigate two electrolyte systems for connecting the photoelectrodes: aqueous alkaline electrolyte solution (pH 14), and alkaline exchange membrane. Achievement of these milestones will represent a significant advance in the technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A sustainable economy relies on renewable energy sources that can be continuously replenished and transiently stored in periods of overproduction. A photoelectrochemical (PEC) cell directly captures sunlight and converts it to an electrical current that would dissipate as heat if not used immediately or stored via electrolysis reactions for later use. The water splitting PEC is designed to electrolyze water into its elements, hydrogen(H2) and oxygen (O2). 

In the three years of the project, the Rutgers team has examined three strategies to advance the performance of PEC devices and lower their cost of fabrication: 1) Develop a new class of wide bandgap semiconductors (oxynitrides) that can be paired with existing narrow bandgap semiconductors (e.g., Si) in a tandem configuration to better utilize the total solar spectrum. 2) Develop synthesis techniques for crystalline catalyst materials that produce conformal thin films of these materials for both the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). These catalysts will be made from earth-abundant elements recently developed at Rutgers. 3) Understand the properties of the interface between the catalyst and photoabsorbing semiconductors that achieve long-term stability free from corrosion in alkaline electrolytes. We synthesized a new member of the perovskite structure family, compositionally ABO3, with simultaneous doping at both B/B’ (Nb, Ta) and O/N, sites and engineered these to serve as photoanodes. A successful fabrication method to produce a thin film photoanode was developed that allowed characterization of the band structure of SrNbO2N and its stability when supported on various substrates (Si, MgO, and Ta). The project also investigated a double inorganic perovskite (CsAgBiBr6) produced using a low-cost solution-based synthesis method and its deposition as a thin film. The resulting CsAgBiBr6film has higher stability in air and relative humidity compared to that of lead-based hybrid organic-inorganic perovskites. This material is not only promising for PEC applications, but also for direct PV electricity.  Novel synthesis methods for creation of thin-film nickel phosphides were developed.  Thin films of Ni2P, Ni5P4and NiP2were tested for HER catalysis and stability and achieved best in class electrolysis performance in a half-cell configuration. Instability of the NixPy-catalyst/ Si-photoabsorber interface due to inter-diffusion of atoms during high-temperature synthesis led us to develop a new passivation layer comprised of ultrathin TiN which achieved more than 5 days of continuous photoelectrolysis with no loss in activity (duration of test). A new method to deposit a stable thin film of the OER catalyst LiCoO2 was developed and its electrolytic performance was shown to be comparable to the same polycrystalline material supported using a Nafion ionomer as a binder which lacks long-term stability. 

This project has trained six undergraduates (Chemistry and Chemical Engineering departments), one predoctoral student and one postdoctoral fellow. The postdoc has taken an industrial position in the semiconductor R&D industry. Two undergraduates have gone on to graduate school (Northwestern U, Columbia U). Two others have won summer internships at SLAC National Accelerator Lab. and the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI). Recruiting visits to three NJ colleges has supported diversity and outreach goals. Work under this grant has produced 4 peer-reviewed publications, 1 submitted manuscript, and 1 in preparation. 

            Overall, this project created new thin-film fabrication methods for photoabsorbing semiconductors and PGM-free water-splitting catalysts, and gave a new understanding of the fundamental material properties at the device level. These advances bring energy conversion from sunlight into fuels closer to reality.
